SEARCH
Module org.myjtools.jexten
Package org.myjtools.jexten

Interface ExtensionManager

public interface ExtensionManager
Central interface for discovering and retrieving extensions in the JExten framework.

The ExtensionManager is responsible for:

  • Discovering extensions annotated with Extension across module layers
  • Instantiating extensions according to their Scope
  • Managing extension lifecycle and caching
  • Resolving extension priorities when multiple implementations exist
  • Performing dependency injection on extension instances

Basic Usage


 ExtensionManager manager = ExtensionManager.create();

 // Get the highest priority extension
 Optional<MyService> service = manager.getExtension(MyService.class);

 // Get all extensions
 manager.getExtensions(MyService.class)
     .forEach(s -> s.execute());

With Plugin Support


 PluginManager pluginManager = new PluginManager(...);
 ExtensionManager manager = ExtensionManager.create(pluginManager);
See Also:
  • Extension
  • ExtensionPoint
  • ModuleLayerProvider

  • Method Details

    • create

      static ExtensionManager create(ModuleLayerProvider layerProvider)
      Creates a new ExtensionManager that discovers extensions from the specified module layer provider.

      Use this factory method when you need to discover extensions from custom module layers, such as those created by a PluginManager.

      Parameters:
      layerProvider - the provider of module layers to scan for extensions
      Returns:
      a new ExtensionManager instance

    • create

      static ExtensionManager create()
      Creates a new ExtensionManager that discovers extensions from the boot module layer.

      This is the simplest way to create an ExtensionManager when all extensions are available in the application's boot layer (no dynamic plugins).

      Returns:
      a new ExtensionManager instance using the boot layer

    • withInjectionProvider

      ExtensionManager withInjectionProvider(InjectionProvider injectionProvider)
      Configures this ExtensionManager to use a custom injection provider for resolving dependencies during extension instantiation.

      This is useful for integrating with external IoC containers like Spring or Guice.

      Parameters:
      injectionProvider - the custom injection provider to use
      Returns:
      this ExtensionManager instance for method chaining

    • getExtension

      <T> Optional<T> getExtension(Class<T> extensionPoint)
      Retrieves the highest priority extension implementing the specified extension point.

      Extensions are sorted by their Priority value, with Priority.HIGHEST being selected first. If multiple extensions have the same priority, the selection is deterministic but unspecified.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the highest priority extension, or empty if none found

    • getExtension

      <T> Optional<T> getExtension(Class<T> extensionPoint, Predicate<Class<?>> filter)
      Retrieves the highest priority extension implementing the specified extension point that matches the given filter.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      filter - a predicate to filter extension classes before selection
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the highest priority matching extension, or empty if none found

    • getExtensionByName

      <T> Optional<T> getExtensionByName(Class<T> extensionPoint, String name)
      Retrieves an extension by its exact name as specified in Extension.name().
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      name - the exact name of the extension to retrieve
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the named extension, or empty if not found

    • getExtensionByName

      <T> Optional<T> getExtensionByName(Class<T> extensionPoint, Predicate<String> name)
      Retrieves an extension whose name matches the given predicate.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      name - a predicate to match extension names
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the first matching extension, or empty if none match

    • getExtensions

      <T> Stream<T> getExtensions(Class<T> extensionPoint)
      Retrieves all extensions implementing the specified extension point.

      The returned stream is ordered by Priority, with highest priority first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      Returns:
      a Stream of all extensions, ordered by priority (highest first)

    • getExtensions

      <T> Stream<T> getExtensions(Class<T> extensionPoint, Predicate<Class<?>> filter)
      Retrieves all extensions implementing the specified extension point that match the given filter.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      filter - a predicate to filter extension classes
      Returns:
      a Stream of matching extensions, ordered by priority (highest first)

    • getExtensionsByName

      <T> Stream<T> getExtensionsByName(Class<T> extensionPoint, Predicate<String> filter)
      Retrieves all extensions whose names match the given predicate.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the extension point
      Parameters:
      extensionPoint - the extension point interface class
      filter - a predicate to match extension names
      Returns:
      a Stream of extensions with matching names, ordered by priority (highest first)

    • clear

      void clear()
      Clears all cached extension instances.

      This forces the ExtensionManager to re-discover and re-instantiate extensions on the next request. Useful when module layers have been modified (e.g., plugins added or removed).

      Note: This does not affect Scope.SINGLETON instances that have already been created and are managed globally.
